title: Federer’s brilliant act of sportsmanship
text:
Roger Federer suggests Alexander Zverev challenge serve fault call in Hopman Cup act of sportsmanship Staff writers, AAP, FOX SPORTS January 5, 2017 10:02am 
ROGER Federer lost his match but won even more fans with a brilliant moment of sportsmanship at the Hopman Cup on Wednesday night. 
Federer was facing German teenager Alexander Zverev, a top prospect, when facing a serve at 15-0, 6-5 in the first set. Zverev’s serve, blasted out towards Federer’s backhand, clipped the back of the line yet was called as a fault. 
“Close,” Federer said, shaking his head and smiling. 
“How close?” Zverev asked. 
“Very close,” Federer replied with another grin. 
Zverev checked on his challenge count before referring the call to Hawk Eye and sure enough, it was in. The German 19-year-old won the point, as Federer did not return the serve - then went on to win the set and the match, 7-6 (7-1) 6-7 (7-4) 7-6 (7-4). 
WATCH FEDERER’S BRILLIANT ACT OF SPORTSMANSHIP IN THE VIDEO ABOVE! 
Federer said he couldn’t be happier with his lead up to the Australian Open, despite the defeat. 
The former world No.1 is returning from six months on the sidelines following ankle and back injuries and believes his preparation for the opening grand slam of 2017 couldn’t be any better. 
The 17-time grand slam winner has played two matches in Perth, beating Dan Evans of Great Britain 6-3 6-4, before losing to Zverev. media_camera Roger Federer of Switzerland serves to Alexander Zverev of Germany. 
Federer is currently ranked 16 in the world and for the first time since 2003 will enter the Australian Open with a seeding in double figures, which he said will make the draw interesting viewing. 
Of the Zverev defeat, the 35-year-old Swiss legend said: “Who really cares. As long as I am playing injury free and feeling good. 
“I actually pulled up really good after the first match and the mixed, the next day, so this one will feel different. 
“I’ll feel muscle pain, which is also one of the reasons why I came here, to have that pain in my body, so hopefully if I do have a tough match at the beginning in Melbourne I don’t have to go through it as extreme over there. 
“I’m very happy. I have played five good sets so far. I am very pleased.” 
Federer’s final match of the round robin event is against Richard Gasquet of France, ranked 18 in the world, on Friday night. And if things go well, he’ll then play the USA’s Jack Sock in the final on Saturday night. 
Time on court is why Federer chose to play in Perth to start his Australian summer. 
“I think (Zverev and I) did very well, over a long period of time and that at the beginning of the season is not easy to do,” he said after Wednesday’s loss.”It was good to play 2.5 hours. It is a great number to compete in, which is why I was really pushing to win the second set, to extend the match and get me into a tough, long match.”
